Award.AwardTitle: Assessing Probabilistic Extreme and Fatigue Responses of Wind-Excited Structures through Integration of Both Uncertainty and Directionality with a System Perspective

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Better modeling and quantification of wind load effects on buildings and structures are essential for structural design and wind hazard mitigation. Wind tunnel studies and structural dynamic response analysis provide information of wind-induced extreme and fatigue responses as functions of wind speed and direction. The overall structural performance to strong wind is then evaluated by a further consideration of variations of wind speed and direction. As the most unfavorable wind direction that causes the largest wind load and structural response under given wind speed does not necessarily align with the direction of strongest wind, consideration of directionality effects can result in more economical design of structures as compared to the analysis with the "worst case" approach of disregarding wind directionality. The discrepancies of predictions from current existing approaches on directionality effect are found to be significant. Furthermore, these approaches cannot account for uncertainty and directionality in a unified framework. Due to a lack of scrutiny on the accuracy and effectiveness of these approaches, and a lack of a unified approach for both uncertainty and directionality, the detailed and comprehensive wind loading information derived from wind tunnel studies may not necessarily lead to expected improvement in the design of wind-excited structures. This research will consider the uncertainty and directionality of wind, aerodynamics, and structural characteristics in a unified framework with a system perspective. Simplified procedures will be developed for possible use in future design codes and standards. The new tools and knowledge can also be used for performance-based design and assessment of structural systems against multiple hazards.

The goal of this research is to investigate transparent and reliable approaches for better assessing probabilistic multiple limit state responses to support a reliability and performance-based design of wind-excited structures. This research has the following objectives: 1) modeling of probabilistic extreme and fatigue responses of non-Gaussian response processes, 2) modeling of directional extreme wind speeds, 3) prediction of probabilistic extreme and fatigue responses considering both uncertainty and directionality, and 4) assessing structural performance with the effects of uncertainty and directionality accounting for multiple limit-state responses. The research findings will help develop consensus on how wind directionality effects are best quantified, thus the large discrepancies of existing approaches can be reduced or eliminated. The framework will also help wind engineering laboratories to better integrate wind tunnel study results with wind modeling for cost-effective design of structures to wind loads.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project carried out a comprehensive study concerning the assessment of probabilistic multiple limit state responses of wind-excited structures with consideration of uncertainty and wind directionality. Advanced approaches have been developed for quantifying alongwind and crosswind responses of tall buildings under stationary and nonstationary wind excitations. These approaches are able to take into account nonlinear aerodynamic damping effects, inelastic performance of buildings beyond linear elastic limit, and transient structural dynamic effects of nonstationary wind excitations. This project established new approaches for identification of nonlinear aerodynamic damping of tall buildings and other flexible wind-excited structures, which are important for evaluation of vortex-induced vibration and dynamic instabilities of flexible structures.  The dynamic inelastic responses of fixed-base and base-isolated tall buildings were also investigated through response time history analysis and statistical linearization approaches. This project also developed an effective computation fluid dynamics (CFD) simulation framework for generating approaching boundary layer flows with target characteristics and dynamic wind pressures and wind loads on tall buildings. The comparison of proposed CFD simulation results with wind tunnel measurement data illustrated the accuracy and effective of the proposed framework.  The CFD simulation tools will be increasingly adopted for determination of wind load effects of structures. There is a critical need for enhancing the accuracy of this promising approach. The new research findings and insights gained from this project provided power tools and improved understanding for better design of buildings against damaging extreme winds. This project also addressed evaluation of system reliability of wind-excited structures considering multiple limit state responses and wind directionality. A simple but accurate framework with closed-form formulations was presented for addressing wind directionality effect, which is more accurate as compared to the single directionality factor approach currently adopted in building design codes and standards. 

The innovative approaches developed from this project can help wind engineering laboratories and structural engineers to better integrate wind tunnel study results with wind climate modeling for cost-effective design of structures to wind loads. The new insights and simplified approach concerning the influence of uncertainties and directionality can be adopted in future design codes and standards, and be incorporated into various documents such as ASCE standards for wind tunnel studies of buildings and other structures. The new tools and knowledge can also be used for performance-based design and assessment of structural systems against multiple hazards. Several PhD students have been directly participated in the research activities and made presentations in international conferences and published papers on professional journals. This project had great positive impact on their professional development. The project has made contributions toward better design of infrastructures and reduction of wind-induced losses.
